Award.AwardTitle: Elucidating the Neural Correlates of False Memories in Young and Older Adults

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Historically, memory declines have been cited as the foremost cognitive deficit affecting older adults (second only to physical ailments, when considering age-related problems in general). However, while the vast majority of research in this domain focuses on the subjective experience of forgetting, false memories - memories for events that never happened - are also a significant contributing factor to age-related memory impairment. With funding from the National Science Foundation, Nancy Dennis, Ph.D., of Pennsylvania State University, University Park, is carrying out research using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to characterize the neural mechanisms mediating true and false memories in both young and older adults. Previous research suggests that both forgetting and false memories are the consequence of the same underlying shift in cognitive processing in aging, that is, an overreliance on familiarity or gist memory (i.e., memory for general features of an episodic event or memory) at the expense of item-specific processing (i.e., memory for specific details of the event or memory). This research project is examining the neural substrates mediating item-specific and gist processing as they relate to semantic, perceptual and conceptual episodic memories. The research is characterizing age-related changes in item-specific and gist processing, and developing a unified understanding of the common and unique neural mechanisms that support true and false memories in younger and older adults.

The research will also provide valuable insight into the ways in which the brain processes true memories. In this way, the research will clarify overall processing shifts in aging and the direct impact of these age-related changes on memory functioning. Furthermore, by increasing the understanding of how older adults encode, process, and retrieve information, the research is contributing to the enhancement of study and testing techniques designed to optimize memory processing across the lifespan. To facilitate this translational process, the research is being disseminated to others at both national conferences and community-attended lectures. Presentations are part of an extensive series aimed at educating seniors in the community about advances in cognition, nutrition, exercise, and other research on aging. This research project also offers educational opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students in the field of memory and the cognitive neuroscience of aging. Students are trained in both behavioral methods and advanced neuroimaging methodologies and analyses. Students learn the importance of integrating psychological theory with neuroimaging methods in order to gain insight into the neural processes mediating cognitive behavior across the lifespan. Experience with experimental design and multiple behavioral and fMRI analyses techniques lays a foundation for students' development as independent researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research provided valuable insight into the ways in which the brain processes both true and false memories. The research also extended our knowledge with respect to overall processing shifts in aging and individual differences in aging that underscored age-related differences in memory functioning.

Specifically, we found that the middle and superior temporal cortex play a critical role in supporting false memories across a variety of experimental paradigms and stimuli. Neural activity in these brain regions were associated with both high and low confidence false memories as well as false memories to semantic, perceptual and conceptually related stimuli. Given the role of the left middle/superior temporal cortex in supporting semantic gist and associations, we suggest that when new information is related to previously studied information, false memories for the new, yet related information arises from the shared semantic labels among the material.

Furthermore, with respect to aging, we found that individual differences in memory performance are a critical factor in identifying neural activity supporting false memories. Specifically, older adults who make the most false memories exhibit neural activity in the aforementioned temporal regions. This suggests that age-related increases in false memory may rely on similar processes in older adults as we see in younger adults, but are not purely driven by age alone. 

The results of this work have made significant contributions to the field of memory, aging, and false memory research. A clearer understanding of these processes is necessary for understanding how false memories are formed and retrieved. These results are useful in helping develop memory training procedures and interventions to help improve memory in aging.

 

At the time of this report, 11 manuscripts describing the results have been published in peer reviewed journals as well as numerous presentation of the data made at conferences including the Society for Neuroscience, Cognitive Neuroscience Society, Cognitive Aging Conference, International Society for Behavioral Neuroscience and International Conference on Memory. Dr. Dennis also presented the results in several talks both within her University and local community. In addition she promoted knowledge with respect to aging and memory function throughout the local community in the form of local talks, articles written in local newspapers and newsletters sent out to community volunteers from her lab.

The grant was also instrumental in reaching out the aging community in State College and Center County by helping expand their knowledge and awareness of other topics in cognition and aging. Through grant-related activities, Dr. Dennis established a aging participant database at Penn State. While helping to support aging labs across campus, participant recruitment for the database includes involvement in community acuities such as Alzheimer's Association Walk, health fairs, and community lecture series. Dr. Dennis has been instrumental in making these connections across the community and within the University.
